reviewText:
This is a long review so if you want just a brief summary of why I recommend Viscera Cleanup Detail: Shadow Warrior skip to Results and read from there.

RuneStorm brings to life all of our dreams by finally making a title where you get to see what happens after you play a game. After playing Viscera Cleanup Detail: Shadow Warrior you’ll learn that maybe you should reconsider before you go out of your way to break everything in a room.

Story:
Lo Wang got in a devastating battle at a temple nearby destroying everything in sight. You are hired as a janitor to clean up a terrible mess. Bodies are everywhere, art is destroyed, and you’re the only man for the job.

Campaign:
There is one level; it’s the same as the first level in the new Shadow Warrior game. It’s your job to clean it up with a mop and your hands. You must deposit the debris into various incinerators, mop up blood, and grab all the cash you can find. The campaign only has two achievements, clean up everything and grab all the money. If you can do this you’ve proven that “you’re the best around and nothing’s ever gonna to keep you down.”

Gameplay:
This game plays similar to an FPS. The camera is always in first person and your two weapons are a mop and your hands. You must pick up garbage with your hands and throw it into incinerators while mopping up gallons of blood. You better keep your mop clean, but beware for some odd reason the machines that provide water can shoot out an organ. Similar to a normal janitor after you are done you must clock out.

Results:
If you have always wondered what happens after a game, wonder what life as a janitor for crime scenes would be like, or even just want to play a game that doesn’t push your wits then Viscera Cleanup Detail: Shadow Warrior is for you. This brilliant game is hilarious to play if you just beat the first level of Shadow Warrior. For some odd reason the character sounds exactly like Lo Wang, which makes me wonder if after he saved the universe he decided to give up fighting and clean up his messes.

Pros:
+You get to experience Shadow Warrior through a whole new light.
+You get to clean up bodies, mop up blood, and steal money… how many games offer that?
+Good graphics
+Easy gameplay, with simple controls.
+Funny dialogue
+Two straightforward achievements
+Its free if you already own Shadow Warrior (2013)
+YOU GET TO BE A JANITOR

Cons:
-Cleaning up everything achievement can be really annoying as a single bullet shell could be the culprit.
-There is only one level (why can’t we clean more)

reviewText:
Viscera Cleanup Detail: Shadow Warrior... OOOHH YOU WANNA CLEANUP SOME WANG?

This game does something I thought nothing could ever do... It made cleaning your mess up fun.
So as an employee of Zilla Corp. You are assigned to clean up the temple that was trashed in the beginning of Shadow Warrior, all the bodies, blood, and damn broken glass.
You use your mop to clean up blood, the incinerator to burn the little bits, and the hazmat bins for the bigger stuff. Find some bloody money? Put it in the suitcase for an extra reward when you clock out... and maybe put a few priceless artifacts in there too. And why not use that dinky little device you received to make sure you didn’t miss anything? And remember, clean with honor.

Wow, was it difficult to decide if I recommend this or not. It’s a cleaning game, so there’s defiantly going to be mixed opinions, for example a friend and I LOVE these Cleanup Detail games, while two of my other friends hate them, and I recommend on if I like a game or not, not if it's good or bad. So there were two ways I could review this, as a good game or as a bad game. I decided I’ll do it as a good game, because I sure as hell liked it.
This, for being a cleaning game, is amazing. Somehow it makes cleaning addicting, I spent an hour just burning stuff and another cleaning up the blood... and I was okay with that!
The visuals, as with Shadow Warrior’s, aren’t too great, but defiantly get the job done. Dialog is amazing with Wang’s witty comments as you burn stuff and find money.

But this game is riddled with bugs and glitches. Sometimes when picking up an object, it sporadically flies through the air, or when you move the suitcase all the money gets throw across the room, and the worst, disappearing objects. After three hours of cleaning and burning, I had found all the money and was getting ready to clock out, but I bumped the suitcase, causing it to glitch out and send one of the rolls of bills flying. Luckily, I watched where it landed. Unluckily, I also watched it fall out of the map through the floor.

OCD people will love/hate this game, and so will anybody with addictive natures. But I doubt any 'hardcore' Call of Duty players will enjoy this for more than ten minutes.

Pros:
Lo Wang's witty comments
revolutionizes cleaning
addictive gameplay
interesting and original mechanics (using incinerator, buckets spilling, Etc.)

Cons:
it’s a cleaning game... Enough said
bugs, glitches, etc.

8/10

reviewText:
I was fortunate enough to win the entire Viscera package in a giveaway, and I'm really happy to own this game. I started with Santa's Rampage, then moved on to this one (will be doing the actual Viscera game soon). I have already reviewed Santa's Rampage, and these two games are very similar. The link to SR has been provided above.

If you like the Shadow Warrior theme, cleaning, and relaxing, casual gameplay, then you will enjoy this game.

Since I have already provided the link to SR, I will be commenting on the differences between the two games (SR and Shadow Warrior).

The aesthetics in Shadow Warrior are very, very good. The building you are in is nicely detailed with different museum pieces, and the variety of things to clean up is good. Like SR, there is a radio you can pick up and carry around if you want some music while you play. The music is very good and matches the theme appropriately - the menu screen music is also really nice. I have noticed that your character actually speaks and makes comments during gameplay - usually when you pick up stuff. The level is also fairly larger than SR, but a lot more symmetrical.

Thus far, I have found no way to kill yourself, so I do not think this is possible in SW. There are only two achievements - completely cleaning the building and amassing 2 million dollars in your trunk. I was unable to find the last bit of mess to cleanup - I scoured the ENTIRE building with my sniffer and just could not find any blood splatters =(. I also ended with 1,875,000 dollars (so close!). I am unsure whether or not the museum pieces are worth money (I had thrown all of them into the furnace), so that might contribute to the final count when you punch out.

The game is still fairly buggy at times - in particular with the ridiculous collision mechanics. Sometimes pieces can just randomly go flying, and I've also noticed that some of the doors will swing around violently. As in SR, the collision mechanics between objects are EXTREMELY sensitive, so consider walking (hold CTRL) whenever you are carrying water buckets and the hazardous waste containers.

Overall, this game is very fun, and you should check it out if you are interested in this concept.

Definitely recommend!

reviewText:
I booted this one up right after beating the Shadow Warrior campaign for the first time.  I'm familiar with the full Viscera Cleanup Detail and the Santa's Workshop stand-alone, but had yet to play either of those, so I was going into this experience with fresh eyes.  Boy, what an experience it turned out to be.  I had seen the trailers, the screenshots, but actually walking into Zilla's dojo to pick up the mess left by Lo Wang was somehow, as boring as the idea of janitorial labor may sound, so cathartic and entertaining.

I'm not sure if the assets were reused ad-naseum from Shadow Warrior, but this stand alone still looks as gorgeous as the base game.  The new parts added in specifically for VCD have just a vaguely more cartoonish style to them than the rest of the game, but it isn't jarring, and just makes things easier to play as you can easily, visually, distinguish what is part of the map, and what is a tool to help you clean it.

In my playthrough, I spent HOURS scrubbing the hell out of the floor, the walls, and burning any body part, organ, or piece of shrapnel that didn't belong.  The tasks were reptitive, but not in annoying way, it felt a lot more like playing something that keeps you coming back despite staying the same mechanically, like Tetris, than it did actually doing a chore like mowing the lawn or shoveling the sidewalk.

Despite all of this, the punchout machine still gave me flak for not completing the job properly, for someone with severe OCD this could probably be maddening, as I walked around the map for a good ten minutes looking for anything I had forgotten to clean up.  I guess even in the virtual space, perfection isn't easily obtained.

This nice little freebie (yes,it comes free with the base Shadow Warrior purchase) has me sold on the main Viscera Cleanup Detail game, and I'm looking forward to seeing how RuneStorm expands upon the concept for a full-blown title of their own design.

reviewText:
Viscera Cleanup Detail: Shadow Warrior

Positives:

+ Excellent cleaning simulator, those looking for a career in cleaning, this is a good start. The game has real life applicability, since the tasks are so simple and boring it pretty much prepares you for your upcoming cleaning career.
+ Free game (included when purchasing Shadow Warrior).
+ Game lasts 1-2 hours, so thankfully the pain of playing is short-lived.

Negatives:

- Horrificly monotonous. This entire game consists of using your mop and bucket to clean blood from the temple floors and then you're expected to dispose of guns, shell casings, katanas, shurikens and severed body parts by placing them in the biohazard bins.
- Experience the sheer frustration and tedium of a cleaner, as you'll regularly mop up your own bloody footprints and walk back and forth to refill mop buckets with water, or get new biohazard bins.

Overall Score 1/10

For anyone aspiring to be a janitor, I really do recommend this incredibly repetitive, dull game. As for the rest of us, avoid. I got it for free with Shadow Warrior, so it didn't cost me a cent. But that still doesn't mean it's good, in fact it's downright bad.

So I bought Shadow Warrior in a humble bundle cause I thought it looked cool, and in my library I noticed this little doo-dad of a game. I had seen the Cleanup game thingy before so I figured I might as well give this a try.

but why

Why is there a game for cleaning?

I play video games to do stuff that I can't do irl. Sure, I can't exactly clean up blood, machine guns, and big wads of cash, but that's because i don't surround myself in that sort of lifestyle, which i'm cool with. Instead of playing this game, why not just do something productive like.. actually cleaning your house?

The idea of a cleaning game is unique, I guess, and I'm not just bashing it because i think it's stupid. I genuinely don't find it fun. You pick up things and place them in other things and then sometimes you tip it over and then you have to stand it up and put everything back in. how is that fun. do you people enjoy this kind of stuff? it's virtual torture.

Viscera Cleanup Detail is a game you will either love or hate, and this little gem serves as a great introduction to the main game of VCD. You are a janitor; and in this case you clean for the Zilla Corporation, making the temple that serves as the prologue for Flying Wild Hog's Shadow Warrior squeaky clean. For best results, play this after you finish the prologue; then you will either be in awe or upset at the mess you made.

Like in the main VCD game, you're a janitor armed with only a mop, a 'sniffer', endless supplies of water buckets and biohazard crates, incinerators, and your own two hands to clean up the messes made by gore and gib happy protagonists like Lo Wang. The cleaning action that you find in the main game is found alive and well here. Even though most of the rooms are red, it is remarkably easy to locate blood and mop it up. Smaller items like tiny gibs and shell casings are kept to a minimum, sure to please longtime players of VCD who routinely come across piles of spent shells. Finally, in a move sure to make this an easy cleanup, you're given two incinerators and two mop bucket generators which will make the job go faster, not to mention that the game generously has spawned a number of buckets and biohazard crates waiting for fresh new janitors to utilize.

So while you are cursing Lo Wang for making your life hard, this level adds a few new things to entertain you while you clean. First off, your janitor has a voice who comments on the messes and whistles to himself. He adds some character to the game (Dammit
date: they used an automatic!). He lapses into repeats after some time but they never wear out their welcome. A radio in the first hall blasts the soundtrack to Shadow Warrior. Finally
recommended: SPOILER FOR SHADOW WARRIOR: remember how in the prologue Lo Wang walks into the hall with two million dollars? A side goal to cleaning up the temple is to collect all of the cash you find and toss it into the janitor's private trunk. It adds some variety to the clean-all-the-things formula that VCD is known for.  END SPOILER\n\nThe game is still not without its glitches

Viscera Cleanup Detail: Shadow Warrior is a stand-alone one-level spin-off of a VCD game. In that game you play as Janitor who has to clean up mess after alien movies massacres. Casual fun and jokish simulator, but amusing. This one came out before main game was even finished in 2013 as free offer to owners of Shadow Warrior. They say that they will merge this one into main game soon.
Oh, and it kinda has multiplayer too.

So, to enjoy the game to the fullest, first you should load up Shadow Warrior and start up new game. Maybe even pick the highest difficulty. Then get into the first fight and take your sweet time slashing people with katana and throwing shurikens randomly at things. Enjoy the blood and massacre. Then once you beat the chapter 0, close the game and load this one up.
Bloody hell, Lo Wang! Just look at all the mess that my alter-ego left!
(No, don't want to say that VCD:SW copies massacre from main game, albeit it would have been awesome)

Then classic gameplay of VCD goes on, cleaning stuff and then running around with beeper to find that last patch of blood that you would in the end fail to see and you will just mop up the spot around.

It shows that this one is the earliest VCD on Steam. Unlike Santa's Workshop, there is almost nothing that can go wrong, no dynamite, no way to kill yourself. Some surface, mostly ceiling, thankfully are mess-proof, otherwise you would have never reached blood on the roof. So you can just move on and slowly clean it up for giggles after main game. Hm, main hero alo throws one-liners, not something I seen in other VCDs. They sound quite familar, albeit get old.

Better wrap this up. As for the main game and Santa's rampage, just take what I said here and apply it to those but the main game is way longer with different maps, other objective to complete, lots of achievements and so much more.

Get these games if it sounds even slightly appealing to you. You won't regret it.

Viscera Cleanup Detail: Shadow Warrior is a stand-alone one-level spin-off of a VCD game. In that game you play as Janitor who has to clean up mess after alien movies massacres. Casual fun and jokish simulator, but amusing. This one came out before main game was even finished in 2013 as free offer to owners of Shadow Warrior. They say that they will merge this one into main game soon.
Oh, and it kinda has multiplayer too.

So, to enjoy the game to the fullest, first you should load up Shadow Warrior and start up new game. Maybe even pick the highest difficulty. Then get into the first fight and take your sweet time slashing people with katana and throwing shurikens randomly at things. Enjoy the blood and massacre. Then once you beat the chapter 0, close the game and load this one up.
Bloody hell, Lo Wang! Just look at all the mess that my alter-ego left!
(No, don't want to say that VCD:SW copies massacre from main game, albeit it would have been awesome)

Then classic gameplay of VCD goes on, cleaning stuff and then running around with beeper to find that last patch of blood that you would in the end fail to see and you will just mop up the spot around.

It shows that this one is the earliest VCD on Steam. Unlike Santa's Workshop, there is almost nothing that can go wrong, no dynamite, no way to kill yourself. Some surface, mostly ceiling, thankfully are mess-proof, otherwise you would have never reached blood on the roof. So you can just move on and slowly clean it up for giggles after main game. Hm, main hero alo throws one-liners, not something I seen in other VCDs. They sound quite familar, albeit get old.

Viscera Cleanup Detail: Shadow Warrior is a 1 hour level themed about the newer Shadow Warrior game released in 2013. Though I never played Shadow Warrior I say others play it and it’s your typical Hack and Slash shoot em' up type of deal with lots of one-liners, loads of guys with swords, guns and excessive amounts of blood. How is this relevant to this game you might be wondering? Well it was produced as a Pre-Order Bonus for buying Shadow Warrior back when it released then given to Viscera Cleanup Detail buyers as well which as a fan of the game I great for us to get a little more content out of the game like they did with Santa's Rampage. Only this time there is only 2 achievements, both of which are very easy to get and leaves you with the rewarding 100% completion if you've completed the level and collected all the cash.

The level itself is pretty simple, 2 large rooms with small connecting corridors connecting them as well as stairs to the upper part of each room which only have a little to clean up. Majority of the mess is in the large room and they provide you with 2 furnaces, 1 in each room so you don't have to keep running back which is nice!

The cleaner takes the role as if he is connected to the Shadow Warrior game with one-liners such as Hey
date: I know this guy... Who's laughing now!" when you pick up a head or "I hope these gloves are thick enough" when you pick up glass shards etc. This makes the level really stand out from the others and adds a little fun to the mix.
